passages.text: (Spec Sales Views Unless Otherwise Noted)
Another crazy day out there in consumer land with more sizeable post- mkt to open reversals (ULTA +7% post last night and now - 5%, GAP - 11% last night and now +1%).
"People trade this retail sector like they have I day to live" remarked one client yday, and we continue to get a lot of puzzled inbounds on price action across the space.
Some thoughts below on those names + research recaps, as well as for some topical names yday (BURL, DKS, BBY, HRL).
Dan Politzer is also out with a great note recapping Macau 2Q25, a space which has been on fire lately.
Thoughts on July PCE from Horvers below as well.

Shares are fading after a strong Q2 comp beat (adding to a long list of crowded longs fading good prints), and a FY guide raise where Bears to picked at the 2H deceleration and step up in SG&A, but Bulls deemed conservative as management expressed "it is prudent to take a cautious approach given continued uncertainty around Consumer spending"

Bulls were encouraged by the strong comp performance which well exceeded Buyside expectations and data reads. Stack math suggests upside to the 2H implied comp guide, and we hear that QTD data continues to track quite well. They also defended the SG&A step up as largely acquisition + incentive comp related, so are less concerned on that front.

While positioning has shifted more long after being a crowded short for most of 2024 and the stock has had a strong move / re- rating, some think it is hard to get too negative here as numbers move higher and ULTA regains share alongside recovering Beauty industry trends.
HORVERS ON ULTA: Upward Revisions Set To Continue; Reiterate OW / Analyst Focus List; Key Mgmt Takes

Chris remains OW / AFL with his \(\) 600\(PT based on 19x his 2027 EPS. Indeed, as he previewed, estimates continue to trend to the\) \ \(25 - 26\) baseline argued post 1Q with 2026 in the \(\) 28 - 30\(, also as expected. Given\) 4\% + \(comp s coming back into play, ULTA's algo, share gains, and the quality of the industry along with ULTA's perch, we believe it should trade at a premium to a normalized market multiple of\) 18x. Three key takes and charts below, full detail and mgmt takes in the note.

One of the best upward revision momentum stories in our coverage as the truth sets ULTA free: High quality comp beat well ahead of his raised into the print forecast and strong flow- thru to the bottom- line + merch margin expansion. Share Gains: ULTA gained share for the second consecutive qtr as Sephora at KSS headwinds fade while the category accelerated on the prestige side (+MSD from +LSD with mass holding at +LSD). Looking Ahead: The company guided the top- line conservatively despite ongoing momentum in the business and no change in behavior from the consumer. On the bottom- line, the step up in SG&A growth is essentially incentive comp, the Space NK acquisition, and variable expenses given the upward sales revision as investment spending is essentially on track (though we continue to see conservatism on this line as well).
Figure 9: Sephora at Kohl's Impact Slowing
Note: the right axis only applies to ULTA cosmetic comp, Sephora @ KSS comp, and Nielsen cosmetics growth Source: Company reports and J.P. Morgan estimates.
Figure 8: Beauty Share of Wallet Largely In-Line with Pre-Pandemic Average
Source: Bureau of Economic Analysis and Morgan Estimates
Figure 4: Circana Implied Quarterly Growth; Mass Continues Outpacing Prestige
Note: calendar quarter basis for mass and prestige total/beauty Source: Circana, CEw, WwD, and Company Management
Another day another reversal from a dramatic post- mkt indication...
GAP was indicating as much as \(- 11\%\) post- mkt yday before the call started...
With Specialty Retail names dropping like flies recently, I asked yesterday afternoon is GAP next to walk the plank? Or could we get an ANF type reversal?

...Shares are now \(+1\%\) and some keys to the recovery were management's call comments around the cadence of recent trends (strong exit rate + momentum into Q3), tariff mitigation, and expressing the long- term margin outlook improvement:

Recent Trend Momentum - "As it relates to back- to- school, the third quarter is off to a strong start. In Q2, May and June were sort of slow because of the weather being so cool, but we really did see July accelerate with more seasonal weather and the drop of our back- to- school product. And August has really continued that momentum as we head into third- quarterwith customers responding well to our back- to- school assortments, I would say, especially at Gap and Old Navy"

Tariff Mitigation - "Excluding the impact of tariffs, this [guide] would imply underlying operating margin expansion versus last year. We do not currently expect the annualization of tars in 2026 to cause further operating income declines next yearand we expect to mitigate the full impact of tariffs over- time, which we believe represents opportunity for operating margin improvement longer- term."

Matt remains OW on GAP with his PT rising to \(\) 32\(vs.\) \ \(29\) prior) based on \(- 5.3x\) our FY27 EBITDA supported by our linear regression analysis relative to GAP's pre- pandemic top/bottom- line growth profile.. Matt models FY25 EPS of \(\) 2.07\(vs. Street\) \ \(2.09\) & raises FY26 EPS to \(\) 2.31\(vs. Street\) \ \(2.38\) .

- July Comp Inflection To Close 2Q - Relative to a sharp acceleration to mid-single-digit comps in July on our estimates, coinciding with the Fall product drop and back-to-school assortment flowed through to stores. On the updated math, \(\sim 90\%\) of the brand portfolio is now driving low-to-mid-single-digit comp growth.

- August Sustaining Exit Rate Momentum = "Prudent" 3Q Outlook - Management's outlook by our work includes an embedded moderation in September/October (vs. current August/QTD trends) despite Sept/Oct 1-year comparisons easing by \(\sim 400\) bps relative to August by our estimates given unfavorably warm weather/hurricanes last year that weighed notably on Kids apparel (Old Navy/Gap brands). Matt's math points to a 2-year stacked July/August comp of high-single-digits, which if sustained throughout September/October would point to 3Q SSS of high-single-digits as potential upside (= more than double 3Q's outlook for \(\sim 3\%\) comps).
- FY25 Margin Outlook = Tariff Trough w/ FY26+ Expansion Opportunity - CFO O'Connell confirmed in our callback
North America Specialist Sales JPM | US CONSUMER: ULTA, GAP, Macau Gaming, July PCE, BURL, BBY, DKS, HRL 29 August 2025

that tariffs are expected to be a neutral impact to FY26 operating margins (vs. net headwind in FY25) as a result of improved mitigation efforts across an increasingly diversified sourcing mix, negotiations with vendor partners post final details in August, product/assortment mix changes, and greater full price selling with FY25's \(6.7 - 7.0\%\) operating margin confirmed as the "floor". Mgmt reaffirmed the model of OPM expansion (inclusive of GPM expansion and SG&A leverage) anticipated at \(+\) LSD% rev growth given the cost structure, pointing to FY26 OPM expansion YOY opportunity (above Street EBIT margins down 10bps YOY). The "transitory" 100- 110bps operating margin headwind from tariffs included within FY25's P/L represents \(\sim\) 30.30 of EPS power - pointing to "fundamental" EPS power in FY25 of \(\sim\) 2.40 & \(\sim\) 2.60 in FY26 (= 21% upside relative to Consensus FY26 EPS of \(\) 2.14\$ ).
Dan Politzer's 2Q25 Recap here
Macau Gaming stocks have been on a heater alongside strong GGR growth, with shares up and to the right since GGR trends started improving in May.

In this note from Dan Politzer: With the 2Q25 earnings season for the six Macau SAR operators behind us, we have looked at market- wide segment gross gaming revenue (GGR) and EBITDA performance as reported by each operator. 3 key takes and charts below with more in the note.

- 2Q25 industry-wide GGR reached 84% of '19 (up 7 pts sequentially)- Company-reported mass table/slot GGR reached 122% of '19 (up 9 pts sequentially, relative to '19) with VIP 29% of '19 (up 3 pts sequentially)- Hold-adj EBITDA across the operators was \$1.94b, 87% of 2Q19 levels (up 4 pts sequentially, with SJM a drag). Visitation
during 2Q25 was steady at 94% of 2Q19 levels (versus \(\sim 95\%\) in 1Q25).
Figure 1: Sequential Changes in Hold Adjusted EBITDA Share
Source: Company reports and J.P. Morgan
Figure 8: Total Macau GGR and EBITDA vs 2019
Source: J.P. Morgan Company reports.
2025 Macau Commentary: Market is continuing its strong upward swing

LVSI think what you see is a continued improvement in the quality of the tourism coming to stay overnight in Macau*WYNNRe: GGR acceleration: I think a mix between improved customer density, but also the calendar of events and the offerings by the operators helping to drive the increased patronage as well*MLCO*Volumes accelerated further in July, which was a standout month despite some weather disruption, with drop up year-on-year and sequentially versus June*MGMRe: MGM China *we continue to see a very strong trend. In July, our performance is pretty robust.MGMWe see our strong volumes across nearly all business segments and the solid market share and margin*MLCO* a lot of the overhang and concern in China around global economy seems to have dissipated. And so people who potentially were worrying about their own business or worrying about the global economic environment are both feeling a little more confident and a little more excited about traveling and spending again*MLCO* I think we’ve carried the momentum that we saw in June into July. I think the market feels good right now.*
Source: Company reports
JULY PCE (Horvers Comments): Goods Consumption Growth Ticks Up; Hardlines Strength Continues

Stepping back, the July PCE report came in ahead of economists' expectations, showing improvement in hardgoods spending (corroborated by the retail sales report) despite broader macro uncertainty (suggesting potential benefits from pricing, in our

view), with 12/18 categories we track accelerating on a sequential basis. More specifically, Motor Vehicle Maintenance, Sporting Goods, and Decor accelerated the most, with Tools & Equipment, Household Appliances, and Auto Parts the weakest. That said, 14/18 categories decelerated on a 2Y basis, led by Flowers, Seeds, & Potted Plants, Motor Vehicle Maintenance, and Sporting Goods, though we note that 3 of the 4 categories that accelerated on a 2Y basis were related to furniture, furnishings, and décor.
Goods share of wallet up slightly — Goods share of wallet was up \(\sim 10\) bps vs. June at \(31.2\%\) of total consumption. This remains slightly below the pre- COVID average of \(31.4\%\) .

Grocery spend sequentially flat, with prices moderating \(\sim 30\) bps to \(+1.9\%\) YOY in July — We continue to expect further grocery inflation in 3Q (albeit at a modestly slower pace; see our proprietary Nielsen analysis).

Tariff prices continue to flow through to hardgoods — Lastly, looking at the PCE pricing data, certain hardlines categories we track are seeing increased inflation (led by Flooring, Furniture, and TVs), perhaps related to tariff- driven price increases. We expect further tariff- related price increases as the year goes on (see our recent WMT CFO and ASO mgmt meetings).
Quite the day in consumer- land yesterday (again)... A few quick notes + research recaps below.

Burlington Beat Factory = Built Different... Comps accelerating & clearing the bar, exit rate strong, and stack math suggesting further comp upside which drives powerful operating leverage and EPS torque. BURL has been a popular HF long, and Bulls see more upside to play for moving forward. Off- Price remains well positioned in the current backdrop. Feedback was positive – not much pushback on this one other than the run that the stock has had potentially setting it up for a near- term breather.
Q2Y/YEPS DayEPSTickerComps% ChgBeatBURL6.7%5.3%30.3%TJX4.0%2.7%8.9%ROST2.0%1.1%2.0%

We like Off- Price here... Matt is OW all 3 and added BURL to the Analyst Focus List in his sector preview calling for Q2 upside, and BURL (along with NCLH) is the name I have been pitching long most over the last few months. Key post- views from Matt below:
Boss on BURL: 2Q Beat w/ "Combination Catalyst" on Tap; Own Off- Price; Overweight & Focus List here
Matt Boss (OW / Analyst Focus List) raises PT to \(\) 348\(based on \~25x his FY27 EPS (5yr pre - pandemic avg). FY26 EPS moves 3% higher to\) \ \(11.37\) .
- Stack Acceleration: \(+800\) bps 2 & 3yr Q2 comp stack acceleration driven by improved branded / quality merchandise and chase capabilities
- Strong Exit Rate: July exiting \(+HSD\% >\) June \(\mathrm{MSD\% > May LSD\%}\)

- Looking Ahead: August = "solid start" with Q3 combination catalyst in Sept / Oct driven by: (1) AUR expansion (with mid single digits in 2Q driven by branding/mix and full-price selling noting minimal like for like pricing), (2) inventory flow-through of branded inventory sourced from 1H tariff-related disruption with favorable reserve inventory providing potential chase opportunity

- Beat & Raise Opportunity: Management set Q3 & Q4 comps 0-2%, noting "as is our practice, we will manage our business conservatively and be ready to chase, with Q2's 2yr stack of \(+10\%\) translating into \(\mathrm{MSD\% + 2H}\) comp growth.

Following the initial FL deal announcement which was viewed in a more negative light, sentiment improved as investors digested the positive prospects for the deal, along with a continued strength in DKS core business that continues to knock the cover off the ball.
Our sense of positioning was still more long into earnings, and the comp bogey seemingly kept creeping higher to \(5\% +\)

DKS printed a 5 handle, but areas of pushback were: Lack of flow- through to margins on strong comps, 2H implied comp deceleration, some concerns on promotional uncertainty, and potential share dilution from the FL deal. There was defense from Bulls, but there was a tactical Bear camp here as the bar got higher and shares rose into the print. Post- view from Chris below:
Horvers on DKS: Business Momentum Continues, Though Gross Margin Adds to the FL Wrinkle; Key Mgmt Takes here

Chris Horvers (Neutral) raises his PT to \(\) 235\(, given the ongoing momentum in the business combined with the Foot Locker overhang, and based on\) \sim 14x P/E \(on his 2027 EPS\) \left(\sim - 8.5x EV/EBITDA, in - line with historical average\right)

- Business momentum continues with topline guidance prudent on 2H uncertainty and DKS's confidence in its business continues to rank highest among Chris' discretionary companies that have reported 2Q with no hesitation around the innovation and newness in its assortment or consistency of the consumer (no BTS hangover expected).- Gross margin lower on tariffs and promotional uncertainty where GPM expansion was a tick below where we would have modeled on a \(5\%\) comp and the company backing off the 75-bp GM expansion guide for the year with 2H increasing more than 1H, but not to the same degree as prior (we estimate GM up 50 bps and more in 4Q given a 30-bp product donation to storm victims in 4Q24). The change was a higher and more certain impact from tariffs (and how that is shared with the brands) as well as promotional uncertainty (although no issues currently).- Share dilution from FL acquisition in focus where the deal is expected to close on September 8th, with the consideration deadline tomorrow after the market close. If FL closes above the \(24 cash consideration tomorrow and all FL shareholders elect stock (the economically rational decision), that is \~11MM additional shares coming in representing \~11% share count dilution. Mgmt noted that even if this occurs, it still expects the deal to be accretive in FY26, though the degree would be less. Net-net, like last qtr, despite strong fundamentals and company execution, uncertainty remains high for the stock with clarity on FL a key unlock.

BBY has been more controversial with sentiment / positioning leaning more negative on the name. Despite the stock's reaction, Horvers notes in his recap that thematically, the tenets of the BBY bull case remain in- tact. Post- view from Chris below:

Chris remains OW with BBY on the Analyst Focus List, but he closes out the Positive Catalyst Watch he had put in place following the stock's pullback below current levels after Q1 earnings, considering his expectation that Q2 would yield upside and this event has passed (he notes he would consider revisiting as we proceed through the Fall). PT moves \(+\) 1 to \(\) 89\(based on \~6x EV/EBITDA and reflects \~12x P/E on our 2027 estimates (and reflects \~7x EBITDA and \~13x P/E on 2026E), below the stock's long - term average valuation but in line with current FYI levels. Six key takes below:

Computing \((- 25\%\) of the mix) comped the comp with Windows 11/gaming/AI all portending continued +MSD trends (likely accelerating post the 2Q iPad launch lap) Switch 2 drove strength in Entertainment (38% US comp) with the mix rising from \(6\%\) of sales to \(9\%\) of sales in 4Q (and the last cycle supporting a similar comp outcome this holiday) TVs (25% mix) and appliances (12%) stabilized with assortment changes, labor investments, and replacement cycles bolstering "less worse" sale trends in 2H Alternate profit pools launched and will become more accretive Underlining the importance of BBY to the brands, vendor support accelerated (e.g., investing in store resets, store labor investment up \(20\%\) YOY in 2H). Specific to alternate profit pools, accretion should also gain speed as its Marketplace grows (just launched and accretive to GM and OM this year), while we believe advertising revenue will turn from operating margin neutral to accretive next year. BBY is also leaning into Tier 2 TV brands (Hi- Sense and TCL) to help TV performance as the consumer remains value- oriented, while it and appliance have optionality to housing/rates (BBY and TGT are the underappreciated housing plays in our coverage) In terms of sales trends: June and July comped \(3\%\) with QTD "LSD," which we believe indicates the upper end of that range considering management is baking in a slowdown in sales post- BTS (and against easier monthly comparisons with 2Q24 months flat in August and \(- 4.5\%\) in Sept/Oct). Lastly, BBY noted that both sales and EPS are biased toward the upper end of the FY guide. Said succinctly, outside of a post- BTS slowdown across retail (so far, management has not seen any evidence

of increased episodic shopping), we believe the narrative path in the stock objectively improved, especially into holiday and considering we view the margin guide as conservative around tariffs and supply chain efficiencies.
While most Packaged Food stocks took it on the chin yday (our weakest Consumer index - 2%), HRL stood out post earnings, and Tom Palmer walks through the key takes below:

Tom remains OW with his PT moving \(\) 4\(lower to\) \ \(30\) and his FY26 / FY27 EPS moving to \(\) 1.44 / \(\) 1.54\(, respectively. For FY26, we assume\) \sim 7\% \(operating profit growth at the high end of HRL's long - term algo of\) 5 - 7\% \(. Tom's Dec - 26 PT of\) \ \(30\) reflects \(18x P / E\) and \(12 / x EV / EBITDA\) , both of which are at the low end of the shares' historic trading ranges (which is probably warranted for now).

- As Tom noted earlier this week (Sentiment Check), we heard some concerns from investors ahead of the print about rising pork costs, but the expected impact was perhaps \(\) 0.01-0.02\(per share and not the\) \ \(0.07\) EPS miss that occurred with lingering headwinds into FY26. After talking to the company, we have a better understanding of why earnings are facing so much anticipated pressure.- Tom also sees reasons for optimism going forward: HRL's volumes are trending better Y/Y than for most food peers and could improve further as Planters laps last year's lingering disruptions: Pricing actions offsetting inflationary pressures (and inflationary pressures could ease on Fall pork seasonality). Turkey margins still likely to infect higher next year. Also possible that HRL baked in some added conservatism w/ it's fwd commentary (not unusual when new CEOs start).- That said, we do not want to brush over the lingering risks: Guidance has seldom proven conservative in recent years, and it is surprising to us that elevated input costs are presenting such an enduring margin headwind, when so much of HRL's portfolio is traditionally able to pass through pricing in a relatively efficient manner
North America Specialist Sales JPM | US CONSUMER: ULTA, GAP, Macau Gaming, July PCE, BURL, BBY, DKS, HRL 29 August 2025
